Chapter on Contemplating the Heavens, Part 25, Heaven of YÄma, Part 11

The bhiká¹£us further contemplate the delightful objects in the heavens, which arise from the combination of faculties, are blown by the wind of discrimination, increase again and again, and are burned by the fire of craving.
The people of the world crave the pleasures there and give rise to this thought:
The heavens are extremely blissful.
In this way, the bhiká¹£us focus their thoughts and contemplate:
Those heavens will be destroyed.
The bhiká¹£us do not give rise to craving and delight in those delightful objects, and their minds are free from distress.
In this way, the bhiká¹£us have the foremost good thoughts and see that the six desire heavens will all be destroyed.
There are twelve kinds of destruction in the four heavenly realms:
First, their strength is inferior;
Second, they always fight with the asuras. Suddenly, the asuras will appear in the dark and enter their army;
Third, when fighting, the asuras strike the heavenly bodies with armor and helmets;
Fourth, when fighting, they push the helmets on their heads into the ocean;
Fifth, after being destroyed, they feel ashamed;
Sixth, when fighting, seeing RÄhu, they become frightened;
Seventh, when retreating, the heavenly maidens abandon them and go to other heavenly sons;
Eighth, when eating, due to their own karma, seeing inferior food, they feel ashamed;
Ninth, the size, color, shape, and ornaments of the army are similar to their own karma, and they feel ashamed towards others who are inferior;
Tenth, when the gods are playing, the birds born among the gods also despise those who are inferior;
Eleventh, inferior gods walk on foot to the place of play;
Twelfth, the inferior gods receive desires and touches that resemble their own karma, but the adornments of others are superior and wonderful. Seeing the superiority of others, they feel ashamed.

In the realm of the Four Heavenly Kings, there are these twelve kinds of destruction. A monk who cultivates the mind well does not crave heavenly pleasures, and observes those heavens with a pure mind.
Having observed them, he becomes disgusted and criticizes heavenly desires.
If there are people who practice pure conduct in order to seek heaven, such pure conduct is not a cause for pure conduct.
Such people are despised by that monk.
Why is it so?
Because they lack mastery.
Furthermore, that monk observes the destruction of the Thirty-three Celestials. He sees
that there are eight kinds of destruction among the Thirty-three Celestials.
What are the eight?
First, when fighting with the asuras, the rain falls impurities due to the inferiority of their armor.
Second, when fighting, seeing the brave asura king, their minds become weak.
Third, when eating, the inferior ones are ashamed.
Fourth, the inferior gods are not recognized by the heavenly king Indra.
Fifth, the inferior gods are inferior in appearance, strength, and all other aspects.
Sixth, the inferior gods' sounds, touch, color, taste, and smell are all inferior and not equal to others.
Seventh, when the inferior gods fall, the goddesses abandon them.
Eighth, when the inferior gods ascend to play in the palace, their spiritual powers are inferior and they cannot progress quickly.
These are the eight things that destroy the Thirty-three Celestials.
The YÄma Heaven has six kinds of destruction.
What are the six?
First, when eating, the inferior ones are ashamed.
Second, the orders of the inferior gods are not accepted by the goddesses.
Third, due to the inferior heavens having little merit and virtue, even if the celestial maidens make offerings to them, it is not as good as making offerings to those with much merit and virtue.
Fourth, when the inferior heavens' Muzhou Loutuo, the king of the YÄma Heaven, expounds the Dharma, their minds are not delighted.
This is the greatest loss and destruction among them.

Fifth, due to the inferior heavens' past karma being meager, their radiance changes. If the heavens in their past lives practiced much wholesome karma, they will sit on a great blue sapphire seat, and after sitting, they will rise again.
The heavens with inferior karma will sit in that place, and the seat will change into silver.
Due to the various types of karma, there are such losses and destructions. Sixth, the size is short.
These six are the matters of loss and destruction in the YÄma Heaven.
The Tuá¹£ita Heaven has four losses and destructions.
What are the four?

First, when the inferior heavens in the Tuá¹£ita Heaven hear the Dharma, their minds are not delighted, and they do not enjoy the sound of the Dharma expounded by the king of geese. This is called loss and destruction.
In Tuá¹£ita Heaven, the king of geese always abides in the ground of undefiled bliss.
That king of geese is none other than a bodhisattva who takes birth according to his wishes, thus becoming the king of geese with the color of his wishes.
The goose's body is filled with the radiance of the seven treasures, with a color incomparable to any, and its bodily radiance pervades five thousand yojanas with various colors.
The radiance of the Tuá¹£ita gods is not as good as that of the king of geese, all of which surpasses them, causing the gods to give rise to a sense of wonder.
Having caused those gods to give rise to a sense of wonder, the bodhisattva king of geese then spoke a verse of the Dharma to them, saying:
The merit and virtue of the gods is exhausted, and their lives quickly diminish.
Always diligently and energetically uphold the Dharma in Tuá¹£ita Heaven.
If one abandons the Dharma and is destroyed by carelessness,
And does not accumulate meritorious virtue, one will later give rise to regret.
Until old age comes, and sickness and death have not yet occurred,
Do not regret it later.ğŸ”½If you do not accumulate merit,
You will be destroyed by carelessness.ğŸ”½Because of being destroyed by carelessness,
You will suffer in hell.ğŸ”½Having obtained complete faculties,
If you do not practice the Dharma,ğŸ”½What is the use of life, wealth,
Relatives, or siblings?ğŸ”½Always create merit,
With a mind that embraces the Dharma,ğŸ”½Or stop evil deeds,
Or sometimes befriend good people.ğŸ”½Using the sharp sword of wisdom,
Cut away the evil branches and leaves,ğŸ”½Destroy the mass of faults,
And sever the continuity of faults.
With heavy wisdom, precepts, and merit, do not crave for things,ğŸ”½Always befriend good men,
Who show the true path.ğŸ”½If you are reborn in the heavens by upholding the precepts,
But are deluded by desire,ğŸ”½And do not cultivate meritorious deeds,
You will always wander in existence.
If one always delights in wisdom and adorns oneself with the precious precepts,
If one fears the snake of desire, then one is the god among gods.
If one always practices the Dharma, then the gods should pay homage;
If one practices in the opposite way, then one enters the evil paths.
The far shore is distant from this shore, but having obtained the Dharma bridge,
If one does not cross over quickly, then one will not be liberated from existence.
The fire of wisdom can burn the firewood of immeasurable afflictions.
What is the meaning of being bound by afflictions and attached to the objects of love?
The thick and heavy defilements of desire obstruct the eye of wisdom,
The Buddha's words are like good medicine, able to remove those obstructions.
The great general of the true Dharma can defeat the army of the thief of desire,
Speaking good Dharma words with the mouth, you should diligently listen and accept.
There are four kinds of perversions that can always deceive and delude;
There are eight worldly dharmas in the world that can cause one to lose everything.
In the powerful river of desire, with a hundred doubts, one cannot cross.
If one uses the raft of superior wisdom, one can cross and reach tranquility.
If a god is close to desire, desire can make the mind deluded.
Always dwelling in the five places, there is no chance of liberation.
Desire is difficult to obtain and easily destroyed, like lightning, what is the use of it?
Desire produces suffering like a knife, like the poison of the kimpaka fire.
Thus it is, being close to it, it also grows like this.
Desire cannot be satisfied, like fire burning firewood.
The deluded gods long for pleasure, not knowing the fear of being burned by faults.
If one abandons unwholesome desires, one will later attain great bliss.
The deluded, having become attached to desire, are tightly bound by desire.
Desire is no different from lightning, then it goes to a different place.
If one indulges in desires, desires become more and more intense,
One is burned by the fire of desire, and after being burned, one reaches the place of burning.
If a god is close to desire, this mind is greatly deluded,
Not aspiring to the dharma without substance, the great bliss among pleasures.
Desire has no nirvana, no bliss, no liberation,
Therefore, do not be close to desire, being close to desire is very bad.
If one is close to the objects of desire, the faculties are not content;
Being discontent, there is no bliss, and tranquility cannot be attained.
One should fear the conditioned realm, the great ocean of birth and death,
Because of the great evil desire and love, always with sentient beings.
Thus on the peak of this mountain, there are various lovely trees,
Relying on them to cultivate meditation, contemplating the arising and ceasing of desire.
The four kinds of truths are tranquil, the wise one skillfully practices,
Fearful of birth, old age, and death, they escape to the other shore of goodness.
The foolish mind does not contemplate, bound by desire and craving.
When desires and pleasures are exhausted, birth, old age, and death are certain to be escaped.
If one contemplates this great suffering, one will not be weary in the ocean of existence.
Out of delusion, one is shot by the arrow of desire and falls into the evil realms of hell.
Out of delusion and the pleasure of desire, one ultimately abandons peace and happiness.
Not knowing fear in evil, death arrives like fire.
Until the time of death arrives, it can destroy everything.
Because it can destroy, it destroys the seed of life.
All for the benefit and peace, a man should be diligent.
Attaining happiness and leaving sorrow and grief, always perform good deeds.
If one removes the treasure of desire, leaves the heat and attains coolness,
Such wisdom is not deluded, and then does not hope for desire.
The goose king spoke this verse to tame the gods.
If the gods are heedless and engage in heedlessness, even if they hear this, they will not contemplate it in their minds.
If the gods enjoy hearing the taming verses and phrases spoken by the geese, they will quickly proceed toward the stage of no outflows and wish to hear the true Dharma.
Having heard the true Dharma, they will give rise to a respectful and reverent mind.
In this way, the assembly of gods, having heard the true Dharma and given rise to a respectful and reverent mind, will quickly run to the hall of conduct.

The gods in that hall of conduct, because they have heard the true Dharma and given rise to a respectful and reverent mind, their radiance will increase a hundred or a thousand times, while the radiance of the other heedless gods will diminish.
In this way, in the heavens, one obtains the fruits of the present life.
Those who enjoy heavenly desires will have less form, and their appearance, attire, and adornments will all be inferior.
This is the first destruction of the Tuá¹£ita gods.
The second destruction of the Tuá¹£ita gods is as follows:

The assembly gathered to listen to the Dharma, with countless hundreds of thousands of millions of beings, and five hundred bodhisattvas residing there. The king of Tuá¹£ita Heaven, named Silent, expounded the Dharma to the assembly, namely the twelve links of dependent origination beginning with ignorance.
When those heavenly beings listened to the true Dharma, they single-mindedly focused their thoughts, listened attentively, and heard it well.
Because of hearing it in this way, their majestic virtues and adornments all became a hundred thousand times more excellent, and they further increased and grew.
If the mind of a god is agitated, the mind is like lightning, and it is like a great wind blowing on the great ocean, causing various waves to move.

Due to the causes and conditions of craving, the agitated mind in this way delights in objects. The majestic virtues, appearance, and adornments of those gods are the same as before, without any further increase or growth. Seeing the superiority of others, the inner mind feels ashamed. This is called the second loss of the Tuá¹£ita Heaven.
The third loss of the Tuá¹£ita Heaven.
If the gods hear the Dharma, their minds will give rise to respect and they will understand as taught, understanding in accordance with the characteristics of the Dharma.
Having understood in this way, their minds will abide in the correct [practice].
The spiritual powers, appearance, and adornments of those gods will all be a hundred thousand times superior, increasing even more.
If those gods do not contemplate the Dharma, their spiritual powers, appearance, and adornments will not increase. This is called the third destruction of the Tuá¹£ita Heaven.
The fourth destruction of the Tuá¹£ita Heaven is this:

When those gods hear the true Dharma, their minds give rise to respect and they single-mindedly recollect and take it up in accordance with the Dharma, single-mindedly upholding it and practicing in this way.
After contemplating for a long time, they then practice.

Those gods respect the Dharma in this way, and due to the superior causes and conditions and the power of hearing the Dharma, their spiritual powers, radiance, appearance, and adornments will be a hundred thousand times superior, increasing even more.
If the gods hear this, they will be unable to practice.
Those gods see the superior radiance, appearance, and adornments of others increasing, while their own radiance, appearance, and adornments do not increase.
Those gods see the superior radiance, appearance, and adornments of others increasing and then feel ashamed. This is called the fourth loss of the Tuá¹£ita Heaven.
'Furthermore, that bhiká¹£u observes the four kinds of loss of the Tuá¹£ita Heaven in this way. Having seen the loss, he observes the NirmÄá¹‡arati Heaven and also sees the loss.
He sees:
Such heavenly supreme bliss still has four kinds of loss.
What are the four?
Namely, first, because of the exhaustion of good karma, the feet have shadows, while the rest of the body all has radiance, but the feet do not.
Therefore, the feet of those gods have shadows, and the light of the other gods surrounds them like mountains. When the gods with inferior light see this, they avoid it.
Those with superior light see it and laugh, saying:
This god is contemptible, because his good karma is exhausted.
When the gods with foot shadows hear this, they are ashamed and distressed, thinking in their minds:
Because my karma is exhausted, this is now so.
All that is complete will certainly be lost and destroyed.
Just as in the human world, because there is day, there will certainly be night. In the same way, here, all that is complete will certainly be lost and destroyed.
If a person has life, he will certainly die. In this way, all that is complete will certainly be lost and destroyed.
In this way, in the world, there is nothing that is complete and not lost and destroyed.
This loss and destruction is the first loss and destruction of the Heaven of Delightful Delights.
The second loss and destruction of the Heaven of Delightful Delights is this:
Just as the cotton in Jambudvipa is very soft, sinking when stepped on and rising when the foot is lifted.
The ground in the Heaven of Transforming Enjoyments is also soft like this.
When the heavenly beings' good karma is exhausted, the ground is not soft, the foot sinks down and does not rise when lifted. Other heavenly beings see this and know that their karma is exhausted.
Some heavenly beings see this and tell the other heavenly beings:
The karma of those heavenly beings is exhausted, and the time of their fall is approaching.
This is the second destruction of the Heaven of Transforming Enjoyments.
The third destruction of the Heaven of Transforming Enjoyments is this:
When the heavenly beings of the Heaven of Transforming Enjoyments are playing, if they go under a tree to play and enjoy themselves, the tree will rain flowers in the heavens.
These flowers cover the ground where they are playing. When the heavenly beings' good karma is about to be exhausted, the tree's flowers do not fall and do not scatter on the ground.
The other gods see that the flowers on the tree do not fall or scatter on the ground, and then they say:
The karma of this god is exhausted, and the time of his fall is approaching.
When the god hears this, he is ashamed and distressed, and thinks in his mind:
I am now about to fall, and will lose this.
This is the third loss of the Heaven of Transforming Enjoyments.
The fourth loss of the Heaven of Transforming Enjoyments.
The Heaven of Transforming Enjoyments will definitely be lost, and the perfection in the heavens will definitely be lost.
What is the fourth perfection that will be lost for the Heaven of Transforming Enjoyments?

It is that each god dwells in a place of jeweled ground. Such jeweled ground is pure and spotless, just like a mirror. The body of one god appears in countless places, seeing various shadows, various forms and garments, and various adornments.

Just as the sun in the human realm is one, but appears in countless places such as lotus ponds and countless hundreds of thousands of places, in the same way, the bodies of the devas appear in countless hundreds of thousands of jeweled lands everywhere, as seen in the bodies.
If the good karma of a deva is exhausted, the body of that deva will only appear as a reflection in a jeweled land, not appearing everywhere.
Having seen such destruction and such appearances, other wise devas, having seen this, will say:
This deva, because his good karma is exhausted, is about to fall and be destroyed.
This is the fourth destruction of the devas of the Heaven of Delightful Amusements.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
The world is endowed with pleasures, but does not realize their destruction.
Endowment is sure to be lost, just as there is night when the sun rises.
Thus, endowment with pleasure, thus, it is sure to be destroyed.
Therefore, love is for a short time.
If the mind loves completeness, or aspires for constant happiness,
If one abandons love, one will always obtain happiness like this.
Heavenly desires and pleasures are not enough, so one enters hell,
All are due to love, this is what the Tathagata says.
If a person enters hell, a hundred times or a thousand times,
Also deceived by the net of love, therefore one obtains such evil.
Those NirmÄá¹‡arati Heavens have these four kinds of destruction.
The bhiká¹£u further observes the four kinds of loss and destruction in the ParanirmitavaÅ›avartin Heavens.
If the good karma of those gods is about to be exhausted, when they are about to fall, there will be loss and destruction.
In those heavens there are many kinds of wonderful garlands and adornments, heavenly flowers do not wither, covering the ground everywhere, the supreme fragrance is incomparable.
The garlands have various colors and excellent light, of which the light of the jewels is not even one-sixteenth.
The garlands have many seven-jeweled bees that always emit heavenly sounds.

When the heavenly karma of the Paranirmita-vaÅ›avartin gods is exhausted and they are about to lose their status, those jeweled-winged bees emit unpleasant sounds, abandon the various flowers and fragrances of those gods, and go elsewhere.
Other wise gods, knowing that those gods are about to fall, tell them:
Now, due to your heedlessness, the time of your fall is about to come, yet you do not realize it.
Having heard this, the gods whose karma is exhausted further see those bees abandon them and go elsewhere.
Those gods themselves know this and think:
My meritorious karma is exhausted.

The sorrow in the mind of such a celestial being is beyond analogy. Because he sees that his own happiness is about to end, his mind becomes as hot as the fires of hell, no different. Except for hell, there is no other fire like this.
This is the first destruction in the Heaven of Free Enjoyment of Manifestations by Others.
Furthermore, in the Heaven of Free Enjoyment of Manifestations by Others, there is a second destruction.
The body of those celestials has the first smooth touch, surrounded by light, shaped like the sun in the human realm, like a firefly.
The light of the necklaces and other various ornaments worn on the body of those celestials appears in the jeweled walls and mountain peaks, just as if seen in a mirror.
When that celestial being is about to fall, the necklaces and ornaments worn on his body, the mountain peaks and walls, do not appear in it.
Other wise celestials, having seen this, say to that celestial whose karma is about to end and who is about to fall:
You are indulging in carelessness, and the time of your downfall is approaching.
The necklaces and ornaments adorning your body have lost their luster, and the jeweled walls and mountain peaks are no longer reflected in them.
The wise god had seen this sign before when other gods were about to fall.
This is the second destruction in the Heaven of Free Enjoyment of Manifestations by Others.
Furthermore, in the Heaven of Free Enjoyment of Manifestations by Others, there is a third destruction.
Namely, when the gods there are about to fall, they will go to that place.
The gods whose karma has not yet been exhausted ride various jeweled palaces with wondrous light, which can travel in three places: in the sky, on land, and in the water.
They move swiftly, unimpeded, without shaking or moving.
But when the gods' karma is exhausted and they are about to fall, those palaces shake and move, and their travel is not swift.
The other gods see their palaces moving and say to them:
Your time of decline is approaching. I have seen this sign before when other gods declined.
When the gods whose karma is exhausted hear this, they are about to part from heavenly pleasures, and the fire of sorrow burns their hearts, no different from being burned by the fire of hell.
This is the third destruction in the Heaven of Free Enjoyment of Manifestations by Others.
Furthermore, in the Heaven of Free Enjoyment of Manifestations by Others, there is a fourth destruction.

If the gods there have not exhausted their good karma, the sounds of the five kinds of music and ornaments are all beautiful and wonderful, and the singing sounds are lovely and delightful, bringing joy to the heart upon hearing them.
If there are gods whose good karma is exhausted, the sounds of the five kinds of music for those gods are not wonderful, and the singing is also like that of a mute.
When the gods hear this, their minds are not delighted. Due to their own karma, a voice speaks from their ornaments, saying:
Your good karma is now exhausted and extinguished, due to your indulgence in carelessness and heedlessness.
You are now about to go to a different world, bound by your karma.
The gods, due to their own karma, hear these adorned sounds. Their minds become extremely sorrowful and they say:
Now, the merits and virtues of the pleasures of the realm are exhausted for me.
The headdresses adorned with various jewels immediately fall off. Having seen this, they experience great suffering.
This is the fourth destruction in the Heaven of Free Enjoyment of Manifestations by Others.

In the three realms, there is no place or thing that is permanent. Everything is impermanent.ğŸ”½In this way, the six heavens are places of destruction. Because the good karma of those gods is exhausted, they will definitely fall from these destructible heavens.
Those who aspire to be born in these heavens by upholding precepts will definitely be like this when their good karma is exhausted.

In this way, the gods of the fifth realm of the Heaven of Perfect Enjoyment of Manifestations of Others' Creations, the night-shining god SuyÄma, in the stÅ«pa of the TathÄgata Kakucchanda, the text of the sÅ«tra shows them, saying:
'You gods should abandon heedlessness and do not act heedlessly.
The taste of heedlessness is suffering, to be experienced in hell. All the tastes of desire are like this.'
When those gods have heard the sÅ«tra spoken by the third Buddha, if there are gods who are heedless, delighting in heedlessness, then heedlessness decreases.
Among the six sÅ«tras, the third sÅ«tra spoken by the TathÄgata Kakucchanda is finished.
At that time, the lord of the YÄma Heaven knew that the minds of those gods had become disgusted, and he said to them:
'You gods have already heard the true Dharma spoken by the great sage, which can exhaust all suffering, abandon heedlessness, and speak the peaceful Dharma for gods and humans.
You heavenly beings have already heard the third Dharma of the TathÄgata.

Now that you have heard the Dharma and Vinaya, diligently practice and listen to the Dharma spoken by other Buddhas. Having heard it, take it up and you will gain benefit. After leaving this heaven, you will not fall into the hells, hungry ghosts, or animals.'
Having said this, the YÄma Heaven King Muá¹£itasmá¹›ti, all the heavenly beings then addressed the heaven lord Muá¹£itasmá¹›ti, saying:
'May the heaven king benefit us and bring us happiness.'
At that time, the heaven lord Muá¹£itasmá¹›ti said to the heavenly beings:

'You heavenly beings, all look at this fourth TathÄgata stÅ«pa, adorned with various precious treasures, shining with immeasurable hundreds of thousands of lights, inlaid with various rare treasures, adorned with immeasurable merits, its light universally covering this heavenly world, filling everywhere.
At that time, the heavenly multitudes said to the Heavenly King:
'We have now seen it.'
At that time, the Heavenly King Muzhoutuo said to the heavenly multitudes:
'You should all now come with me to the TathÄgata's stÅ«pa.'
The heavenly multitudes replied:
'Yes, Heavenly King!'

At that time, the Heavenly King Muzhoutuo and the heavenly multitudes went together. Having arrived at the Buddha's stÅ«pa, their minds were pure. They bowed their heads in respect to the TathÄgata's stÅ«pa. Their minds became cool and refreshing. Having paid homage, they rose and looked at the TathÄgata's stÅ«pa.
The TathÄgata's stÅ«pa was radiant with various wonderful jewels, as described above.
On the jeweled wall inside the Buddha's stÅ«pa were the words of the scriptures, benefiting gods and humans. It was said:
If a person can accomplish seven dharmas, they will be reborn in the heavens.
What are the seven?

First, it means that a good man hears the Dharma and understands its meaning. Having heard the Dharma, he practices it well and with a good mind. He takes up the Dharma he has heard and, having heard it, becomes firm. Having heard it, he upholds it and, having heard it, delights in it, giving rise to joy in his mind.
This good man is close to a teacher who is endowed with seven kinds of merits.
What are the seven kinds of merits that the teacher is endowed with?
They are: first, practicing as one speaks;
second, being close to others as one speaks;
third, being able to practice as one speaks, firmly taking it up;
fourth, attaining the Dharma and contemplating it firmly;
fifth, abiding in the mind;
sixth, being close to those who practice the same good deeds;
seventh, not taking others' faults when taught by others.
Being close to such seven kinds of teachers who are endowed with merits.
What is meant by practicing as one speaks?

Knowing this, they practice well and act well. If they have something to say, they know the proper amount and speak little, but it is beneficial. They speak at the right time and in the right way, not hastily or slowly, with much meaning and few words, beautifully, easily understood, in accord with the Dharma, benefiting themselves and others, and speak in this way.
As they say, they practice in this way.
How do they approach others and practice as they say?
Always practicing correctly with body, speech, and mind, their mind is pure inside and out, like true gold. That person practices in this way as they say.
What is meant by practicing as they say and firmly embracing it?
If there is something to be done, they do it purely. They observe the three kinds of actions, and after purifying them well, they are reborn among humans and gods up to nirvana.
Such a person, either thinking for themselves or hearing from others, firmly delights in the joy of the rewards of this karma and firmly embraces it.
One should know that such a person is firm and steadfast.
How does a good man attain firm and steadfast contemplation of the Dharma?
It means firmly and steadfastly grasping the benefits of the two worlds, and seeing in this way, one contemplates firmly and steadfastly.
One who has such a firm and steadfast mind may attain firmness and steadfastness in good karmic fruits from others, or having contemplated oneself, one delights in true reality.
How does one who delights in true reality abide in knowledge?
Having heard much, one's mind is then unconfused, this is called abiding in the mind.
What is meant by associating with those of good karma?
It means seeing the same merits in others as oneself, and having seen in this way, one then associates with them.
How does one not take on others' evil due to others' teachings?
One cannot be led astray by others' non-Dharma or seemingly good dharmas.
One who associates with such a good man who is endowed with these seven kinds of merits will either be reborn among humans or in the heavens.
This is said to be the first dharma.
What are the remaining six dharmas that, when accomplished, lead to rebirth in the heavens?
They are: being learned, practicing what is taken up, being diligent, mindful, not causing distress to others, and not deceiving. These are the six.
These seven dharmas have been explained.
One who accomplishes these seven dharmas, when the body perishes and life ends, will be reborn in the good destinies, in the heavenly world.

Just as when a king or minister rides in a great seven-storied palace, with the sounds of the five kinds of music, singing and dancing, laughing and playing, adorned with wonderful garlands, they proceed in this way to the place of play.
In the same way, if a person accomplishes these seven dharmas, they proceed to the heavenly realm.
What is meant by being learned?
It means hearing the true Dharma, and after hearing it, taming oneself and not giving rise to arrogance.

As they hear, their learning increases, and they practice diligently without being complacent in their wisdom. They always consult others and do not proclaim their own virtues to others, nor do they recite their own names.
Those who are learned, when their body perishes and their life ends, are reborn in a good realm, in the world of the gods.
This is the second factor that accords with proper entry into accomplishment in practice.
What is the third practice of embracing?
It means to embrace and practice what one has heard.

If someone, having heard the Dharma, embraces and practices what is not the true Dharma, then having merely heard the Dharma, they bear the heavy burden of the Dharma, but do not practice or cultivate it, and do not attain the fruit of the Dharma.

If someone else subdues themselves with the hook of wisdom and observes precepts, if their wisdom is not tranquil, then their observance of precepts is like a lamp in the daytime, without light, not firm, and not real.
If there is a combination of wisdom in the precepts, that person is like a lamp with light, firm and real, attaining results that are not in vain.

If one cultivates the Dharma, one can be said to be firm, not just verbally speaking to be firm. That person's physical, verbal, and mental actions are all tranquil, and upon the dissolution of the body and the end of life, they are reborn in a good realm, among the heavenly worlds.
This is the third Dharma.
What is the fourth called diligence?
Laziness is called non-action.
What is meant by non-action?
Following the practiced Dharma, having initiated it but not completing it.
Such a Dharma can be completed through diligent effort without interruption. If one is lazy and not diligent, it cannot be completed.
One who initiates little will not fully practice worldly dharmas and supramundane meanings.

If one is lazy, everything one does will be weak and inferior, and one will be despised, disparaged, and looked down upon by everyone. One will suffer distress, and upon the collapse of the body and the end of life, one will fall into a bad realm of existence and be reborn in hell.
Such a person is destroyed by laziness.
Laziness should be abandoned like fire, like a sword, like falling off a cliff, like a poisonous snake.
If one is destroyed by laziness, one will not be diligent and will lack majestic virtue, no different from a sheep.
Such a person will be ignorant and will not know how to do anything, whether it is wise or unwise, whether it is Dharma or non-Dharma, whether it should be done or not done.
Why is this?
Because of not reading the sutras and not hearing the Dharma, due to laziness.

If there are people who discuss opening the mind and intention, regarding what is known by wisdom, whether it is Dharma or not Dharma, they know all of it. Whether it should be done or not, whether it should be practiced or not, they know all of it.
Such dharmas, which are known by wisdom, they know all of them.
Wisdom and diligence, the lazy do not have.
Those who are lazy are no different from the blind. When their body perishes and their life ends, they fall into a bad destination and are born in hell.

Such people, in terms of the meaning of transcending the world, are all inferior. They experience the utmost suffering. They beg in other people's houses. They always rely on others' doors, hoping for alms. They always look at others' faces. Their complexion is the worst. Their hair covers their eyes. Their eyes are dry. Their toenails and skin are all withered. They go from house to house in the four directions, begging for food. They live a hard life, despised by all.
For this reason, one should abandon all laziness.
If one is diligent and makes effort in the opposite way, everything one does will be accomplished, up to nirvana, let alone other worldly dharmas.
When the body perishes and life ends, one will be reborn in a good realm, among the heavenly worlds.
For these reasons, whether gods or humans, all should abandon laziness and diligently make effort.
At that time, the World-Honored One Vipashyin Buddha spoke a verse, saying:
Laziness, deceit, arrogance, harsh speech,
Abandoning wisdom and so forth, these are grounds for ruin.
Associating with bad friends, abandoning good friends,
Or having wrong views and so forth, these are causes for ruin.
Not knowing good from bad, speaking at inappropriate times,
Or trusting women and so forth, these are grounds for harm.
Associating with whom and whom, eating where and where,
If one does not benefit oneself, this Dharma causes people to despise one.
If one's courage is destroyed, if one loses mindfulness, or if one is hated by the king,
Or if one's mind is obstinate and so forth, this Dharma leads to untimely death.
If one does not understand the fruits of karma, or what is Dharma and what is not Dharma,
And if one is separated from good spiritual friends, one will fall into the evil paths.
If one is lazy or sleeps a lot, or if one is attached to various flavors;
If one is angry, or speaks deliberately false words, or speaks harsh words;
If one is greedy, or arrogant, and one's mind moves away from the Dharma;
If one indulges in sexual desires, or praises the Dharma of sexual desires,
Then there are these three faults, with laziness as the root;
If one is diligent and makes effort, then one will be free from the faults of the defilements.
All those who are diligent and make effort will definitely accomplish the fruits,
As one should be diligent and make effort, one will definitely obtain the fruits of one's actions.
Such three kinds of karma can obtain three kinds of fruits,
Three aggregates and three fundamental roots, definitely three kinds of existence.
' The Buddha Vipashyin's stupa wall was inscribed with these verses, criticizing laziness. When the heavenly beings saw this, they said:
'We will definitely abandon laziness.
From this laziness, there are branches and leaves, as the Buddha said.'
' The lazy, whether gods or humans, in all their activities at all times are inferior.
Whether gods or humans, those who are not lazy, in sequence, reach nirvana.
This fourth Dharma, among humans and gods, has much to do and much benefit.'
' Moreover, the fifth Dharma has much to do and much benefit, namely mindfulness.
What hinders among all dharmas is called laziness.'
In the same way, all worldly dharmas that lead to nirvÄá¹‡a are mindfulness, which is the root.
Whether one is a renunciant or a layperson, if one is mindful and not negligent, and practices non-negligence, all undertakings will be accomplished.
Such a person repeatedly performs actions in accordance with the Dharma, diligently makes effort, and practices with a focused mind according to his aspirations.
That person protects the five faculties from the five sense objects, and his mind is not deluded.

When the eyes see forms, they do not give rise to desire and attachment for those forms, nor does the mind delight in them. Seeing forms as they truly are, one knows their basis, seeing what causes and conditions give rise to such forms.
Having seen forms in this way, one's mind is not disturbed or confused. In this way, those forms cannot lead [one astray], because one sees them as they truly are.

Whether they are renunciants, householders, gods, or humans, they know the faults of form, desire, and form. Having extinguished the faults of form, they recollect and know in such and such a place, the mind takes that form as its object. For such an objective condition, the eye consciousness arises together.
Because of that objective condition, fear arises in me. This stainless recollection can eliminate afflictions. With this recollection, I have already eliminated such objective conditions and fears.
In this way, fear arises due to conditions.
With regard to all objective conditions, because the mind correctly recollects the foremost hopes, one is then able to eliminate the fears of immeasurable kinds of objective conditions.
Recollection takes conditions as its object and is able to eliminate. Within each moment of recollection, it gradually eliminates and progressively eliminates.

It is just as in the world, a skilled copper craftsman places a fine copper vessel in the fire and then refines it. In this way, he repeatedly enters the fire and refines it, diligently and without rest, gradually eliminating impurities and making it smooth and pure.
In this way, good thoughts repeatedly remove defilements, and then become pure.
It is also like a potter who, through the combination of causes and conditions and long practice, makes a lump of clay into a pot.
Such a person diligently gives rise to thoughts and cultivates causes and conditions, like a pot produced from conditions.
Right mindfulness observes, like wearing clothes.

From the beginning, thought after thought reaches the end. In this way, good thoughts are first given rise to, and in sequence, all faults are exhausted, and one sees the truth and is marked by the sage's seal.
Those fault characteristics are exhausted, and because the fault characteristics are exhausted, people then know it.
Therefore, if there are those who wish to attain goodness, they should be truly mindful at all times.
If the eye conditions form, the rope of mindfulness binds the mind, causing it to not move, like taming a bad horse.
In this way, good mindfulness first upholds past objects, and after grasping and contemplating them in this way, it also blocks present eye objects, with ninety-eight thoughts.
What is mindfulness abiding?
Namely, giving rise to lustful desire, improperly observing the wind, unable to make it move.

Thus contemplating the four noble truths of suffering, accumulation, cessation, and the path, in this way and in that way, there are innumerable kinds and innumerable forms, causing all lustful desires to be completely pacified, or causing all lustful desires to be completely extinguished or greatly diminished.
What is the power of this good dharma?
Namely, mindfulness is its root.
All good dharmas are based on mindfulness. Thus turning and practicing, this mindfulness is present.
What is mindfulness of future dharmas?
The future has not yet come, has not yet arisen, has not yet been seen. How can one be mindful of those objects?
If one obtains an object, then one can be mindful of it.
In the future, objects have not yet come into existence. How can one be mindful of them?
Although what one is mindful of is still in the future, one sees the characteristics of causes and conditions and takes the future as one's object. In this way, one can be mindful of it.
That is to say, seeing someone who cultivates good bodily, verbal, and mental actions, having seen them, one thinks:
Such a person will definitely be reborn in the heavens.
If one sees a god who engages in evil actions, having seen them, one thinks:
Such a god will certainly fall into hell.
Thus, knowing this fifth principle, there is much to be done and much benefit in the realms of humans and gods.
The sixth principle is that which brings much to be done and much benefit in the realms of humans and gods.
The sixth is not to torment others.
If one does not torment others, one's mind is tranquil and does not give rise to discrimination, thinking:
Here there is pure conduct, here there is no pure conduct.
Seeing others' bedding, medicine, and necessities, one does not give rise to criticism or self-praise, nor does one say:
I can uphold the precepts.
If one upholds the precepts a little or recites the sutras a little, one does not boast about oneself in front of donors.

With an impartial mind towards enemies and friends, always thinking of the Three Jewels, not associating with those who violate the precepts, not troubling those who uphold the precepts, not frequently visiting donors to obtain resources, with a gentle and pliable mind, frequently consulting and requesting Dharma teachings, the teacher always abiding in solitude, always at all times associating with those who practice the brahma conduct.
A person endowed with such merits does not trouble others. Because of not troubling others in this way, there is much to be done and much benefit.
The seventh principle that brings much accomplishment and benefit to gods and humans is this: namely, not deceiving.

Concealing one's own merits, removing evil karma, with a sincere mind, content with one's robes and alms bowl, always begging for food, dwelling in mountain valleys, caves, forests, and trees, content with the food obtained, with an impartial mind without high or low, not wandering among people without a reason;
Suspecting the presence of insects, not going there;
In marshy areas, they do not walk along water's edge or in ditches, fearing to kill insects;
They do not curse thunder, lightning, or rain, causing them to fall and kill;
They do not speak of the auspicious and inauspicious aspects of stars, planets, lunar and solar eclipses, seeking wealth, food and drink offerings to sustain their own lives;
They do not constantly visit the homes of a single patron;ğŸ”½They also do not walk with their heads held high, looking up;
They also do not move their lips, pretending to recite;
They do not speak loudly or in private;
They do not wear mixed-pattern socks, shoes, or boots;
They do not tie their bodies with miscellaneous ropes, and do not wear multi-colored fragrant pouches on their bodies;
They do not keep bedding and other items;
Those lacking the merit of precepts do not enter the great assembly;
They do not allow others to go to cities, villages, and other places to speak of their own observance of the precepts, seeking offerings;
They do not disturb their minds in various places, do not crave or seek, and do not live near villages;
Do not enter the homes of old acquaintances, relatives, and others without restraint, and do not bring them under your control;
Do not expose others' faults, do not conceal others' virtues, and do not speak of others' real faults in private;
Abandon women as if avoiding evil snakes, do not speak with women, and do not walk with them.

'Do not go near flowering trees, and do not wander in delightful gardens and groves, fearing to hear delightful bird sounds, fearing that hearing those sounds will agitate the mind of desire, therefore do not wish to hear those bird sounds.
Do not sit in meditation near noisy water rivers, fearing that hearing those sounds will agitate the mind.
Do not sit in meditation or walk near fragrant flowers,
Why is it so?
Fearing that the mind will be agitated by smelling the fragrance with the nose.

He also does not watch various birds, birds of various colors, geese, ducks, parrots, peacocks and other lustful birds. He does not watch, see, or approach them in their activities, fearing that his mind will be moved, fearing that seeing the causes of animal women will arouse lustful thoughts.

He does not sit in meditation near coconut trees, breadfruit trees, jujube trees, mango trees, bilva trees, kapetha trees, palmyra trees, or various forest trees such as kashu, fearing that thoughts of craving their flavors will arise.
Abandoning fruit trees, he dwells in a quiet forest, without flavors to crave, without many people.

Meditating thus in the peaceful garden forest of the practice of bliss, diligently applying effort, fighting against the enemy of afflictions, his mind always undisturbed, he does not even take soil from plowed fields as a condition for building a monastery.
Thus, having cut off craving, he used an iron bowl that was patched with string to receive food and drink, and did not think of bowls made of copper, silver, and so forth.
He did not keep three bowls;
The kÄá¹£Äya robe he wore was not turned inside out;
During the summer months, except for going to the toilet, he did not walk even a single step, fearing it would kill insects;
When eating Å›amÄ« fruit, he ate the good fruit and did not eat the rotten fruit.

When eating small jujubes and so forth, he did not look at them and did not eat them. If he ate pears, kiwifruits, soft jujubes, or rotten beans and so forth, he did not look at them and did not eat them, fearing there might be insects inside.
He never removed the insects that grew on the walls of his own house, fearing to injure them, fearing they would die.
He sat in one place and did not look at others' bowls, fearing greed for food.
When walking, he did not walk too close to others, fearing to obstruct them.
On land where there are insects, he does not defecate or urinate, fearing to injure or kill insects.
When begging for food, he looks at the ground one fathom ahead, with a sincere mind;
He always associates with those of sincere mind.
Such a bhiká¹£u does not accumulate things, does not hope for anything, does not delight in seeing rare things, and always diligently sits in meditation. That good bhiká¹£u is thus not deceptive.

That good bhiká¹£u thus upholds the precepts purely without transgression, thus has a pure livelihood, thus has a pure and good mind internally. Such a bhiká¹£u, as taught in the precepts, firmly upholds them without transgression.
As that good bhiká¹£u thinks in his mind, thus the path arises. Always having a pure livelihood, there arises a good intention, not delighting in inferior births, wishing to be born in a good realm.
' At that time, the World-Honored One VipaÅ›yin Buddha spoke a verse, saying:
'The person of pure livelihood, with tranquil body, speech, and mind,
Sitting in meditation and free from desire, they are not far from nirvana.
Those who practice asceticism and are not negligent, dwelling in charnel grounds, under trees,
Constantly dwelling in such places, they are not far from nirvana.
Using dust and dirt as bedding, with a single broken bowl,
Content with the food of roots and fruits, such a person practices with ease.
For those liberated from desire, always delighting in contentment,

The World-Honored Buddha thus praised the virtuous bhiká¹£us who are not deceitful or deceptive.
'Those who possess these seven qualities are good men;
If they engage in desire, they will sink in the ocean of birth and death, becoming animals, though their forms may be human, they are truly not human.
If one can accomplish these seven dharmas, one will be praised by good people, and when the body perishes and life ends, one will be reborn in the good destinies, in the heavenly worlds.
Having experienced heavenly bliss, one will fall back and be reborn among humans, and then attain nirvana, due to remaining karma.

The first good ones are these seven dharmas, namely, from the beginning, associating with good spiritual friends, subsequently listening extensively, embracing and practicing, not being lazy, mindful, not causing distress to others, and not deceiving. These seven dharmas are not deceitful dharmas. Due to the causes and conditions of these seven dharma treasures, one is reborn in the heavens.

If one attains the seven dharmas in the heavens and so forth, one should not engage in heedless conduct, causing one's merit to be exhausted. Having fallen from the heavens, one will fall into the hells, hungry ghosts, or animals.
Therefore, the heavens should not engage in heedless conduct, causing themselves to be destroyed. In all existences, there is no one who engages in heedless conduct and attains happiness.
If one accomplishes these seven dharmas among humans, one will be reborn in the heavens.
There are three causes and conditions by which one, having fallen from the heavens, will fall into the hells, hungry ghosts, or animals.
What are the three?
Not hearing the true Dharma;
Associating with bad friends;
Not believing in the fruits of karma.
If one does not accomplish these seven dharmas, one will fall into the hells, hungry ghosts, or animals.'
At that time, the lord of the gods Muzhoulou told the assembly of gods:
'All of you have already heard these things.
The World-Honored Buddha, with a compassionate mind, has already spoken in this way for the benefit of sentient beings.'
At that time, the assembly of gods all said to the Heavenly King:
'We have now heard this sutra spoken by the Tathagata.
The World-Honored Buddha, out of compassion for the world, has already brought benefit and, in order to eliminate negligence, has spoken in this way.'
The god-king Muzhouloutuo told the heavenly beings:
You have heard this sutra, do not act carelessly.
Because of carelessness, heavenly beings are born in the hells, hungry ghosts, and animals.
Why is this?
You have traded with great value and precious things to obtain rebirth in the heavens here, now you should not let it all be wasted due to carelessness.
As the Buddha said, such sutra teachings should be embraced and practiced correctly, and carelessness should be abandoned.
